skills.name: Find the prime factor decomposition of a number in non-index form
Find the prime factor decomposition of a number in index form

explanations.A: You have found two prime numbers here but 11 x 13 = 143. We need prime numbers that multiply to give 105. Start by thinking what 105 can be divided by.
explanations.B: 105 is in the 5 times table because it ends with a 5. 5 is also a prime number and 105 = 5 x 21. 21 is not prime, so we need to find the factors of 21 that are prime. 21 = 3 x 7 and 3 and 7 are both prime. So the prime factors of 105 are 5, 3 and 7. Writing 105 as a product (multiplication) of its prime factors, we have 105 = 3 x 5 x 7.
explanations.C: You have found a pair of factors that multiply to give 105. But we only want factors that are prime numbers. Are 5 and 21 both prime numbers? We need to keep breaking up any factors that are not prime until our product (multiplication) only contains prime numbers.
explanations.D: 105 is not a prime number as it has other factors, apart from 1 and 105. What other whole numbers could we divide 105 by? The final digit might give you a clue.

explanations.A: You have found a pair of factors that multiply to give 150. But we only want factors that are prime numbers. Are 5 and 30 both prime numbers? We need to keep breaking up any factors that are not prime until our product (multiplication) only contains prime numbers.
explanations.B: You have found some factors that multiply to give 150. But we only want factors that are prime numbers. Are 2, 5 and 15 all prime numbers? We need to keep breaking up any factors that are not prime until our product (multiplication) only contains prime numbers.
explanations.C: 150 is in the 10 times table because it ends with a 0. 150 = 10 x 15. 10 and 15 are not prime numbers so we need to find the factors of 10 and 15 that are prime. 10 = 2 x 5 and 2 and 5 are both prime. 15 = 3 x 5 and 3 and 5 are both prime. Therefore 150 = 10 x 15 = (2 x 5) x (3 x 5). So the prime factors of 150 are 2, 3 and 5. Writing 150 as a product (multiplication) of its prime factors, we have 150 = 2 x 3 x 5 x 5.
explanations.D: 150 is not a prime number as it has other factors, apart from 1 and 150. What other whole numbers could we divide 150 by? The final digit might give you a clue.

explanations.A: Tom has found a pair of factors that multiply to give 45. But we only want factors that are prime numbers. Are 5 and 9 both prime numbers?
explanations.B: Prime factors must themselves be prime numbers. 3² x 5 = 3 x 3 x 5 =45. 3 and 5 are prime numbers so Katie is correct. The 9 in Tom's answer is not a prime number, as we can express 9 as 3 x 3. So Tom is not correct.
explanations.C: The product of prime factors can only be made up of prime numbers. Are all the numbers that Tom and Katie have used in their products (3, 5, 9) also prime numbers?
explanations.D: At least one of the people is correct. Check whether each multiplication (product) gives an answer of 45 and only contains factors that are prime numbers.

explanations.A: Prime factors must themselves be prime numbers. 2² x 5 x 13 = 2 x 2 x 5 x 13 = 260. 2, 5 and 13 are prime numbers so Tom is correct. The 65 in Katie's answer is not a prime number, as we can express 65 as 5 x 13. So Katie is not correct.
explanations.B: Katie has found a pair of factors that multiply to give 260. But we only want factors that are prime numbers. Are 2 and 65 both prime numbers?
explanations.C: The product of prime factors can only be made up of prime numbers. Are all the numbers that Tom and Katie have used in their products (2, 5, 13, 65) also prime numbers?
explanations.D: At least one of the people is correct. Check whether each multiplication (product) gives an answer of 260 and only contains factors that are prime numbers.

explanations.A: The four numbers circled in the factor tree are the prime factors, and so 56 ≡ 2 x 2 x 2 x 7. We can simplify 2 x 2 x 2 to 2 cubed so 56 ≡ 2³ x 7.
explanations.B: I think you have written the three 2's in the factor tree as 3 x 2 instead of multiplying them all together.
explanations.C: I think you have written down all of the factors that appear in the tree rather than just the prime factors at the ends of the branches.
explanations.D: One of the answers is correct. It may help to know that ≡ means 'identical to' and can be used instead of =. How can we use the factor tree to create a multiplication that gives us 56?

explanations.A: I think you have written 3 x 3 as 3 cubed. How should 3 x 3 be written?
explanations.B: 3 x 15 does equal 45 but have we used all the results of the factor tree? We want to include all the prime factors.
explanations.C: I think you have written down all of the factors that appear in the tree rather than just the prime factors at the ends of the branches.
explanations.D: The four numbers circled in the factor tree are the prime factors, and so 45 ≡ 3 x 3 x 5. We can simplify 3 x 3 to 3 squared so 45 ≡ 3² x 5. None of the answers here show this correct answer.

explanations.A: Not quite! 2 x 2 x 2 x 2 is NOT the same as 2 x 4. Remember to use index notation when the same number is being multiplied by itself.
explanations.B: Not quite! I think you have taken all of the individual prime factors and raised them all to the power of 4. This gives us an answer of 1296 instead of 48. Try listing out all of the prime factors (including duplicates) and simplifying.
explanations.C: Not quite! 2 x 2 x 2 x 2 is NOT the same as 4 x 2. Remember to use index notation when the same number is being multiplied by itself.
explanations.D: To break 48 down into its prime factors we can keep dividing by 2 (a prime number). 48 = 2 x 24; 24 = 2 x 12; 12 = 2 x 6; and 6 = 2 x 3. Therefore we have 2 x 2 x 2 x 2 x 3 = 48 as our prime factors, which can be simplified to 2 to the power of 4 multiplied by 3.

explanations.A: To break 80 down into its prime factors we can keep dividing by 2 (a prime number). 80 = 2 x 40; 40 = 2 x 20; 20 = 2 x 10; and 10 = 2 x 5. Therefore we have 2 x 2 x 2 x 2 x 5 = 80 as our prime factors, which can be simplified to 2 to the power of 4 multipled by 5
explanations.B: Not quite! I think you have taken all of the individual prime factors and raised them all to the power of 4. This gives us an answer of 10,000 instead of 80. Try listing out all of the prime factors (including duplicates) and simplifying.
explanations.C: Not quite! 2 x 2 x 2 x 2 is NOT the same as 4 x 2. Remember to use index notation when the same number is being multiplied by itself.
explanations.D: Nearly! I think you have mixed up two of your digits here. Try listing out all of the prime factors (including duplicates) and simplifying.

explanations.A: I think you have done the calculation 2 x 2 x 2 x 2 x 2 x 2 x 5 here. Think carefully about what the numbers in index form mean (2³ and 3²). Try writing each one out as a multiplication first.
explanations.B: I think you have done the calculation 2 x 2 x 2 x 3 x 2 x 5 here. Think carefully about what the numbers in index form mean (2³ and 3²). Try writing each one out as a multiplication first.
explanations.C: I think you have done the calculation (2 x 3) x (3 x 2) x 5 here. Think carefully about what the numbers in index form mean (2³ and 3²). Try writing each one out as a multiplication first.
explanations.D: In expanded form, 2³ = 2 x 2 x 2 and 3² = 3 x 3. So the calculation we are doing is 2 x 2 x 2 x 3 x 3 x 5 = 360

explanations.A: I think you have done the calculation (2 x 2) x (3 x 3) x 5 here. Think carefully about what the numbers in index form mean (2² and 3³). Try writing each one out as a multiplication first.
explanations.B: In expanded form, 2² = 2 x 2 and 3³ = 3 x 3 x 3. So the calculation we are doing is 2 x 2 x 3 x 3 x 3 x 5 = 540
explanations.C: I think you have done the calculation (2 x 2) x (3 x 3) here. Think carefully about what the numbers in index form mean (2² and 3³). Try writing each one out as a multiplication first. And make sure you include all the factors in the multiplication.
explanations.D: I think you have done the calculation (2 x 2 x 2) x (3 x 3) x 5 here. Think carefully about what the numbers in index form mean (2² and 3³). Try writing each one out as a multiplication first.
